turns.content: how do create a white noise layer instrument in logic pro

To create a white noise layer instrument in Logic Pro, you can follow these steps:

1. Create a new software instrument track by going to File > New > Software Instrument Track.
2. In the channel strip for the new track, select an empty instrument plugin slot by clicking on it.
3. From the plugin menu, choose "ES2," which is a synthesizer that comes with Logic Pro.
4. In the ES2 interface, select "Init Patch" to start with a blank slate.
5. In the oscillator section, set the first oscillator to "White Noise" by clicking on the waveform display and selecting it from the menu.
6. Adjust the envelope settings to taste. For a simple white noise layer, you may want a short attack and decay time and a sustain level of 0.
7. Adjust any other settings in the ES2 as desired, such as filtering or modulation.
8. Play some notes on the software instrument track to hear the white noise layer.
9. To further customize the sound, you can add effects plugins to the channel strip, such as EQ or distortion.

That's it! You now have a white noise layer instrument in Logic Pro.
how do I modify the pitch

To modify the pitch of a white noise layer instrument in Logic Pro, you can use the pitch bend function or transpose the MIDI notes.

1. Using the Pitch Bend function:
	* Click on the software instrument track to select it.
	* In the Piano Roll Editor, select the notes you want to modify.
	* Click on the Pitch Bend button in the toolbar (it looks like a line with an arrow pointing up and down).
	* Click and drag the pitch bend line up or down to raise or lower the pitch of the selected notes.
2. Transposing the MIDI notes:
	* Click on the software instrument track to select it.
	* In the Piano Roll Editor, select the notes you want to transpose.
	* Click and drag the notes up or down to raise or lower their pitch.
	* Alternatively, you can use the Transpose function in the MIDI Transform window to transpose all selected notes by a specific interval.

You can also use the ES2's pitch controls to adjust the overall pitch of the instrument. In the Global section of the ES2 interface, you can adjust the Master Tune or the Pitch Bend Range to change the pitch of the instrument across all notes.
